author: baylego
title: Pretty Cool
review:
I bought this today at my local TRU in Colorado. It looks pretty cool when finished, but it's kind of small.

 The canister is the same quality as the larger canisters, but only a little bit larger than the agori boxes. The design on top of the canister is the maze on the skrall shield. On the back, it says you can make a gold accented tahu with the spare gold piece from all six of the sets. The gold piece in this set is a round bohorok shield. The two new pieces in the set are the rakashi's head and spine ( which are connected), and the translucent orange piece under his head. The yellow pieces are the same hue as Mata Nui's armor.

 Overall, the set is nice, and I would reccomend picking this up if you see it.

author: legojango
title: cool, but not cool
review: I bought this yesterday and when i got home i realized: "there's never been a yellow rahkshi before!" i opened it up, but it uses those new one-piece limbs, so it's not that good. I really look foward to the gold bionicle though

author: jumper3485
title: Rahkshi
review:
The rahkshi is easy to move. It comes with a gold piece that's fight-able. But there is no new staff parts. It has a new awesome spine. It has a neck piece to make it longer. (it's a new piece!) The new rahkshi is awesome. It's a rahkshi of heat vision. 


           Pros: 
                easy to move
                gold piece*
                color and spine
           Cons:
                 no new spear parts
                 looks fat (with the one piece)






        *A bohlrahk kal piece og magnitissim.

author: peahats
title: Bionicle Stars: Rahkshi
review:
Rahkhi is yellow and grey with red eyes and a new mask/back. He is armed with a staff the has rahkshi Guurahk (8590) tips. He comes packaged with a shield for the golden bionicle.

Pros:
1 resembles Orignial rahkshi
2 great colors
3 good price

Cons:
1 cannot bend Knees or Elbows

author: SWfreak
title: FINNALY!
review:
Hurray a yellow rahkshi! I just got to remember it's power. Anyways on to the pros and cons.

cons:

small
hard to move the joints with his staff like that
hard to put the head on

pros:

cool colors
gold piece

author: CadKatarn14
title: Best Evil Star
review:
I got all the stars for christmas and all the bad guys are good, but this guy is my favorite. This particular rahkshi is the rahkshi of heat vision that will be spoken about later in the storyline. Now lets talk about the pros and cons.

Pros:
- one piece head [except for eyes]
- nice claw feet
- cool yellow peices
- good gold shield

Cons:
- wish it came with krataa.

Overall, this is a grest set.

author: 1999thomasb
title: You call this a Rahkshi?
review:
This, is just a joke! I can build something even better than this, like a Titan or, a real Toa!

This is why I like and dislike this set

Pros

  • New and Yellow
  • Golden Part 

Cons

  • Fused Parts(Those very cheep)
  • I he has his staff on, hand and arm movement is limited
  • You can't put a Kratta in.
  • Fused Part a Soft Plastic and a break if abused
  • Head movement limited.

author: michaelvader
title: 3rd BEST STAR!
review:
Yeah oh and Piraka is my 4th fave star. So this guy is really cool. I have never had a Rahkshi before so this is so AWESOME TO ME! The staff i really cool and I think those are new pieces. But this guy has A LOT of playability. The bilud is really cool and getting like the backbone on is really hard.

overall A HUGE 5/5 or 10/10!

author: Alemas
title: Rahkshi's back!
review:
Overview

The original Rahkshi sets were launched in 2003, and now, in the final year of Bionicle, they return!

Building Experience

Dreadfull. It took me 5 minutes to build this, and 4 minutes of them were spent trying to get the Rahkshi head to attach to the body, thus destroying what already was a bad build! 1/5

Parts

Hmm... we get the old staff ends of 8590 Rahkshi Guurahk, a rubber Rahkshi head, and a golden shield piece. Not so good. 2/5

Playability

Truly dreadfull. You can barely move the head, arms and legs! 1/5

Value for Money

Â£6.99?!? Terrible! 2/5

Overall

Terrible. The terrible playability destroyed this set, and this set doesn't deserve anything higher than a 2. Not recommended unless you're a collector. 2/5
Alemas

author: TheStormingTrooper
title: Whats old is new again
review:
I love this set! for kids like me who were 3 years old when bionicle came out this is awesome! I just wish that they COMPLETELY remade the set *cough* Head Piece *cough*

pros and cons

 

PROS:

Nice remake

cool head

staff

golden bionicle piece

 

CONS:

Not enough pieces

Not a Perfect recreation

author: benjadude11
title: nice and evil
review:
Woohoo! Rahkshi! This guy is fabulous. He is way, way better than I thought. The color scheme is new and fantastic and the staff is very good, if it is a little bit limiting. Quick piece of irony: the first Rahkshi debuted bendable elbows and knees. Now, the last Rahkshi don't have them. Pros and Cons: 

Pros:
Sweet color scheme
nice feet 
nice spine/neck piece
very nice looking, especially with Takanuva locked in combat
bright red eyes

Cons: 
staff gets in the way of moving the arms

Overall, he is the second best star. I can't put it into words, but imagine the meanest, sleekest most perfect bionicle villain ever. Then multiply the meanness and sleekness by ten. Then add the best color scheme ever. That is Rahkshi.

My star ratings are as follows: Tahu, Rahkshi, Gresh, Takanuva, Piraka, Skrall. Skrall is the only one that isn't totally awesome.

author: LEGOwikiguy
title: My double tazer will destroy you! Along with my heat vision...
review:
When I first saw this set, the first thing I thought was, "That looks awesome! What could be wrong with it?". Well, I was off a bit. The stick is annoying because it has limited movement options (Except for stab, hang, and a few others). The price is not really perfect, $5 USD would be best, but oh well. Good enough. Here are the Ps and Cs (instead of Qs and As):

Pros:

1. Semi-good price
2. Gold shield is a good and rare piece to build Golden Bionicle
3. Intimidating look
4. Posable, including head can turn far to look to side
5. Sturdy, pieces stay together very well

Cons:
1. Stick has limited movements, being 3 different pieces connected to fists
2. Head can't look down, just straight, to the side (Sorta), or up

All in all, 3.5/5 is the best rating for this set. The mask is connected to the spines, which connect to the back. This may need some help with building. Make sure you DO NOT lose the gold parts, these are important.

I recommend this set to any Bionicle Stars fan out there!

author: NickBrick
title: Best of the stars!
review:
He is the best of the Bionicle stars.I know what you are thinking that tahu is the best well actuly Rahkshi passes him up big time.but tahu is cool.I will just do some pros and cons.

                                           Staff is awsome
                                           sweet faceplate
                                           intresting build
                                           transparent orange piece
                                            classic Bionicle weapon
                                             Yellow

                                         Con.
                                  the only con I can think of is that his arms are a little short but its okay.

                                          5 out of 5 great job Lego!

author: kenhew
title: It feels just right
review:
This is my first ever Bionicle and it was purchased when I was checking out my local TRU for new sets, but found none and I had to get something Lego related, so on a whim I purchased this.

Now having no idea what Bionicle was all about and about to purchase one, why did I choose Rahkshi? Well first of all the character design itself is quite nice. With nothing to base on except the boxart, the pose itself just won me over. Secondly the colors, good combination of black(which i later realized is actually dark grey) and yellow. Last is the weapon, which is like a bo staff ending with spears on both ends.

After playing with it for two days, I realized the bionicle series is really a gem. There's so much playability. The Stars series are smaller than previous series, but to me it is just the right size. I incorporate it into my City sets and have it standing on rooftops terrorizing civilians, and it didn't felt out of place.

All in all, I'm pleasantly pleased with this set

Pros

  • Cool character design
  • Nice colors
  • Smaller than previous series and easier to play/manipulate

Cons

  • Arms and knees are pre-bent
  • Expensive (I paid RM50 which is about US$15 - that's how expensive LEGO is in my country!)

You bet I'll be getting the rest before LEGO retire this line this year!

author: KodakKid365
title: Rashki is pretty cool.
review: The spear is nice, but it should have some extra pieces so you can hold it in one hand. But you can have him have two daggers in one hand. The spears on his back are pretty cool, and his claw feet are as well. And of course, he comes with a golden piece. But the tiny arms seriously annoy me.

author: Odeinoichus
title: Bionicle Stars a Last Gasp before the end
review:
Set # 7138 Rahkshi: I just purchased this set a few days ago from Wal-Mart on sale for 5$ CND. I have wanted to pick up the Bionicle Stars to showcase the Bionicle series for my collection because they aren't as expensive to get as the others. Now all I need is the other five to complete the whole set.

 

On to review: Rahkshi represents the villains from the first full-length Bionicle Movie (Which I have.) and the third group of villains, with Bohrok being second and the first villains basically just being over-grown animals.

 

The new parts for this set are very new to me - I collected the Bionicle figures back when they first came out and always wished they had proper looking hands, now these Bionicle Stars use new pieces. Real looking Hands and everything.

 

Bionicle is of course Technic related and much of the building involves parts that normal Lego Theme sets don't use - they are not scaled for Mini-Figure use - unless you decide to stretch your imagination a little. The newer Bionicles from this, the final wave of Bionicle figures before Hero Factory starts are using less pieces than ever before, Lego made some really interesting looking parts and design choices for these little sets.

 

I like it. There may be some who find flaws with it, but for 5$ I can't really argue with the neat factor and the impressive choices that the engineers made in order to give us a full representation of all the factions in this universe. I look forward to picking up the other six to complete my Bionicle Stars Collection.

 

I recommend this to any Bionicle fans who don't mind cutting corners or twenty second builds. I also recommend it to any fans who have been sitting on the fence about it. And the yellow coloring just adds to the impressiveness of this model. At least in my eyes.

author: matoro99
title: Heat Vision!
review:
This is one of the only 2 bionicle stars I liked. It's a little more challenging to build than tahu or takunuva due to the fact that it's hard to slip the head plate over the body. It has some very exclusive parts and should appease part collectors. It's playable, so, everyone should be happy with it. Now, for the pros and cons:

Pros

  • Collectible parts (hey, that rahkshi shell is pretty rare)
  • Gold color (Way better color scheme than 2003's Rahkshi)
  • Classic design (But, 2003's desing is better)

Cons

  • No Krataa
  • Shrunken down
  • Weird staff heads

Overall, this is a prettty good set. Sadly, there is no krataa or cool 2003 rahkshi pecies but, look on the bright side- you always have heat vision!

author: tkettle9719
title: Makuta's sons have arisen again!
review:
I got this set from my dad on my birthday, and I am really pleased by this remake of the greatest normal-priced villains ever.

Pros

  • The staff is really nice.
  • I also like the mask, and how similar it is to the original.

Cons

  • The lack of armor on this little guy is disappointing.
  • It is also a bit short in length.

This set is really great, and has a real Bionicleness to it. It's sad to see all of these guys go, to be replaced by the evil Hero factory. Bionicle Forever!

author: Palmpou
title: Thoughtless reboot and not you should get
review:
I do not actually own the set, but found the unopened box in one of my good friends houses and we opened it together and built it.

Let me get this over with right now for people who are simply want a verdict.

This set is VERY bad, not worth the money, not worth the time.

I am not sure why so many people review saying how excellent it is, but I completely think otherwise, and here is why.

 

A: The price.

This set is supposed to be a reboot of an old one no? So why is it, that with only half the parts of predesscesor, it costs so much more?

B: Piece quality.

The pieces included in the set are very VERY poor. They are only utilized for set and set alone. They are irregular shapes, hard to interface with other lego pieces, and in the case of our set, did not have consistent color among the yellow pieces, what with being different shades of yellow. Also included a random piece whose only purpose was to be put on another model.

C: Construction.

It is very easy. With so few pieces, a complete lack of ingenuity and lack of 'small' parts, it could be pieced even without the manual.

D: Playability.

The set actually does have a strong point. Because of how simple it is, it can easily be tossed, thrown around, posed, and still be fine. Has an articulating neck and all, and even if pieces come of, they are very easy to reattach. However, it still doesnt really do more than just posable action figure.

 

Now for my personal spin.

Along with the original toa sets, I picked up the original rahkshi up because of its gearbox pieces and joints (because I build suspensions with lego pieces). However, I bought two so I could actually construct one of them instead of cannibalize it. And let me tell you, it was a blast. Articulating heads, bestial head, stubby little arms and massive feet combined to make something threatening and imposing. It was easy to build and charming because of the gearbox shoulder (which although was really simple and lackluster was still fun), popping spine, and interlocking pieces that fit together beautifully. It had good build integrity and strength (I could throw it around all over the place with no fear) and it was just fun!. It also came with a neat little micro cd which gave you an awesome bit of cg footage, a set of pretty dumb desktop backgrounds and some music too. Not only that, all of its pieces could be easily used with the lego technique system allowing me to make some pretty cool things (INCLUDING MY FIRST DOUBLE WISHBONE =D ). They also could combine into a weird monster centauer or other things if you wanted.

 

All that for less money than this tripe. The new rakshi set has no redeeming features whatsoever, not one. Go on old toy stores and find one of the six old ones if you want a rahkshi. There is far more value and fun packed into that 2003 set this rubbish thing.

Even if I look at the set alone, it still suffers from the fact its pieces are very hard to use with other lego parts and how much it costs for so few pieces.

author: ArchOnua85
title: Before They Say Goodbye
review:
So the "Stone" element of the Stars series turned out to be the Rakshis. Yes, Makuta's 2nd oldest minions, only predated by the Bohroks (which were not featured after 2003). So how does it stand up?

You know it's not going to be a positive review when I have my criticism covers the entire product's aspects in one go. Because the Stars series tend to be scaled-down takes on the most beloved icons, pretty much everything suffered as a result. The already repetitively anaemic building experience now struck a whole new low, although I have to admit attaching the spine is a little unusual. But besides, this feels much like the original run of Hero Factory because it indeed predated the 2010 models. And by this point, I am not too nice on Hero Factory.

Back to the topic, you would think playability would remain at 2 out of 5, but while I never played with an original 2003 Rakshi (I will however), I remember my Stars Rakshi being rigid by size, unlike the older Rakshis who are so tall you have more leverage for the swings. With this said, alongside with parts, it is humble to slam an 1 out of 5.

Regarding the value for the money, it's not the best ... but it's not the worse either. 30 dollars in 2021 is tremendously cheap, but its features are already sub-par, so 2 out of 5.

In all honesty, maybe I am unfair in my reviews. After all, others reviewers pretty much always tend to have much nicer things to say than I do. And yeah, there is the "Golden Armor" collection making the stars Rakshi mandatory. But while all my loose parts are going to be donated, there are no ways I would buy it again, as it doesn't make sense to me when I keep the golden shield with me and plan to acquire Panrahk.

author: ThoughtLash
title: The Final Rahkshi
review:
The Rahkshi of Heat Vision was the final Rahkshi released by LEGO in 2010, seven years after they were originally released.

Box/Instructions

The STARS line came in small cans, which features caps in the colors of the respective sets. The RoHV's canister had a picture of the creature, a yellow cap, and the basic set info/parts count/age. I don't remember the instructions for either of my Rahkshi, but I got two with no misprints.

Parts

Mostly grey and yellow parts,and most of the pieces came from the 2008 Av-Matoran. The staff came from 8590 Guurahk, the blue Rahkshi in 2003. The yellow pieces are the main excluive pieces, with a custom head mold. Two Shadow Matoran feet are included in yellow, as are two hand, which can be found on 8989 Mata Nui.

The build

This was SO easy, only slightly harder than an Av-Matoran, which were some of the easiest BIONICLE sets ever.

The completed model

Looks pretty nice! The RoHV is a cool little set, which makes a good miniaturized version of the original versions. There are no features whatsoever, other than hand/arm/leg/foot/head (somewhat) articulation.

Overall opinion

The RoHV is a nice set, although there are some serious flaws (no Kraata, Guurahk staff, etc). I would say get it for parts, or if you're a collector. It's not a must have set.

author: Nmfrey23
title: My First LEGO Set
review:
This was my first LEGO set that I built. It's crazy to me that I built this guy 12 years ago. I know that Bionicle STARS certainly isn't revered by fans, but this set has managed to hold a special place in my heart. Out of the six sets from that wave, this one is still my go-to favorite.

Pros: 

New Parts: Shadow Matoran feet are new in yellow, the Bohrok Kal shield is new in gold, and the 08' mould eye piece is new in translucent red. The rubber head piece is a new part altogether.

Overall look: This is arguably the best looking set from the STARS line. The extra leg piece used as a neck piece looks passable in this set. I also like how this set introduces a seventh Rahkshi type in yellow.

Cons:

Poor limb movement.

Head movement is very limited because of the rubber head piece.

Low complexity: The figure is made of 17 parts.

Some may not like the open socket joint present on the neck.

 

While the STARS sets aren't very good on their own, I like this set if only for the fact that it was my first time building LEGO. While I'd recommend any of the 2003 Rahkshi over this, If you're interested in seeing what the final wave of Bionicle was like, this set is probably the best with which to do so. 3/5
